intro: Vignea juncoides, commonly known as the marsh morning glory, is a flowering plant native to wetlands and marshy areas in the southeastern United States. It is a member of the Convolvulaceae family, characterized by its trumpet-shaped flowers and twining stems. The plant typically grows up to 1.5 meters tall, with heart-shaped leaves and pale blue to violet flowers that bloom in early spring. Vignea juncoides thrives in moist, nutrient-rich soils and is often found in wetland habitats. Its botanical features make it an important component of aquatic and riparian ecosystems.
